G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, which grants jurisdiction over civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 9.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 9, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Middlesex County and Defendant conducts business therein.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty to lawful visitors to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers of which it knows or should know.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing on occupiers a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants. Although the excerpt provided is only a concurring opinion focused on the treatment of trespassers, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707 does state that owners/occupiers owe lawful visitors a duty to maintain premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers they know or should know. The proposition is therefore accurate, but not directly reflected in the quoted concurrence alone.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707, not included in the excerpt provided]: The common law distinctions between invitees and licensees in determining the duty owed by an occupier of land are abolished. Henceforth, an occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable man in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner or occupier owes a duty to lawful visitors to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers of which it knows or should know.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition and warning of dangers the owner knows or should know. Although the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, the court’s articulation of the premises-liability duty directly matches the proposition.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988).”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff, as a lawful business invitee, a duty to maintain its premises in a condition that was reasonably safe for customers shopping in the aisles.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional duty owed to invitees and then applies that same reasonable-care standard to all lawful visitors, including business customers, for hazards from snow and ice. It states that a property owner must use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to repair, remove, or warn of dangerous conditions on the property. This aligns with the proposition that a business owes lawful invitees a duty to maintain its premises in a condition reasonably safe for customers shopping in the aisles.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: If the plaintiff was an invitee, defined as a person invited onto the property by the property owner for the property owner’s benefit, … the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” … This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers…

Berard v. Hildreth, 215 Mass. 492 (1913).proposition: A reasonably prudent retailer in the same or similar circumstances would have foreseen that unsecured heavy items placed high on open shelving could fall and injure customers.
Berard v. Hildreth, 215 Mass. 492 (1913).support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with an interpleader action involving bank deposits, a disputed $10,000 check, and the bank’s potential double liability. It does not address premises liability, retailers’ duties, foreseeability of falling merchandise, or any facts involving unsecured heavy items on shelves. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about a reasonably prudent retailer foreseeing injury from unsecured items on high shelving.
Berard v. Hildreth, 215 Mass. 492 (1913).relevant_excerpt: “This is a bill in equity in which the plaintiff seeks to interplead the two defendants in respect to a fund of $10,000 alleged to be held on deposit by it… In such a case it is plain that a bill cannot be maintained by the bank to compel her and the executor to interplead. As was said in Fairbanks v. Belknap, 135 Mass. 179, 184, ‘The office of such a suit is to protect a party, not against a double liability, but against a double vexation on account of one liability.’”

Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd., 319 Mass..raw_text: Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd., 319 Mass. 92 (1946)
Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd., 319 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s actions and omissions constituted negligence under Massachusetts common law and applicable safety standards.
Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd., 319 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that, on the evidence, a jury could properly find the manufacturer negligent under Massachusetts common law in manufacturing and bottling a product (perfume) that foreseeably caused skin burns to an ultimate consumer. The court explains the standard of care, foreseeability of harm to consumers, and the evidentiary showing sufficient to infer negligence, and then reverses the judgment for defendant and orders judgment for the plaintiff on the jury’s negligence verdict. This squarely supports the proposition that the defendant’s actions and omissions constituted negligence under Massachusetts common law product-safety standards.
Carter v. Yardley & Co., Ltd., 319 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Assuming a duty of care, a finding of negligence in the manufacture and bottling of the perfume was proper if the jury found a greater likelihood… that the harmful ingredient found its way into the bottle through want of care of the defendant or its servants than through excusable accident or the act of a stranger… In this case the defendant had full control of the manufacture of the perfume… we think that a finding was warranted that in some way the defendant was negligent… the verdict in favor of the plaintiff was warranted.”

Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.raw_text: Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mass. 790, 794 (1987)
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries and damages.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.case_name: Solimene v. B. GRAUEL & CO., KG
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion certainly involves causation and a jury finding that the defendant’s negligence led to plaintiff’s injuries, but the cited portion does not itself establish a general rule that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s damages. Instead, the court discusses that causation and superseding cause are generally jury questions and upholds the jury’s verdict on that basis. Thus, the case is about who decides proximate cause and when a superseding cause cuts off liability, not a statement that the defendant’s negligence was, as a matter of law, the direct and proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries.
Solimene v. B. Grauel & Co., KG, 399 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Generally, questions of causation, proximate and intervening, present issues for the jury to decide. … The judge left this issue to the jury. The jurors determined that any negligence of the employer was not a superseding cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. … The plaintiff has the burden to show that Grauel’s negligence caused her injury. … The plaintiff sustained her burden by proving that there was a greater probability that the harm which occurred was due to causes for which Grauel was responsible.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Plaintiff exercised due care for her own safety at all relevant times.

Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.raw_text: Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sch., Inc., 408 Mass. 393 (1990)
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.proposition: Defendant is responsible for the negligent acts and omissions of its employees and agents acting within the scope of their employment.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.case_name: Worcester Insurance v. Fells Acres Day School, Inc.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses vicarious liability principles and explicitly concludes that, on these facts, the intentional sexual assaults were outside the scope of employment and do not give rise to vicarious liability for Fells Acres. While the case recites the general Massachusetts rule that employers may be held vicariously liable for employees’ intentional torts committed within the scope of employment, its holding is that this standard is not met here. Thus it does not affirmatively support the broad proposition that the defendant is responsible for negligent acts and omissions of its employees and agents acting within the scope of employment; it primarily denies vicarious liability on the specific facts presented.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.relevant_excerpt: “An employer may be held vicariously liable for the intentional tort of an agent if the tortious act or acts were committed within the scope of employment. Miller v. Federated Dep’t Stores, Inc., 364 Mass. 340 (1973). ‘[C]onduct of an agent is within the scope of employment if it is of the kind he is employed to perform . . . ; if it occurs substantially within the authorized time and space limits . . . ; and if it is motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer ...’ (citations omitted). Wang Laboratories, Inc. v. Business Incentives, Inc., 398 Mass. 854, 859 (1986)… Under this standard, the conduct alleged here does not trigger vicarious liability.”}

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Plaintiff suffered and continues to suffer physical pain, emotional distress, medical expenses, and lost earnings as a direct result of Defendant’s negligence.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: The opinion in Payton v. Abbott Labs does not address or endorse a standard damages allegation that a plaintiff has suffered physical pain, emotional distress, medical expenses, and lost earnings as a direct result of a defendant’s negligence. Instead, it focuses on whether Massachusetts recognizes a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical harm and on prenatal injury and causation issues in DES litigation. It neither articulates nor applies the typical damages formulation stated in the proposition, so it does not support that proposition as authority.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "We conclude that when recovery is sought for negligent, rather than intentional or reckless, infliction of emotional distress, evidence must be introduced that the plaintiff has suffered physical harm... In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable and in violation of the duty of reasonable care owed to Plaintiff and to the public.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The case does not find that the defendant’s conduct was unreasonable or that he violated any duty of reasonable care owed to the plaintiffs or the public. Instead, the Supreme Judicial Court affirms summary judgment for the defendant because plaintiffs failed to prove causation and failed to show any hazardous condition known or reasonably knowable to the defendant. The opinion therefore rejects, rather than supports, a claim that this defendant’s conduct was unreasonable or a breach of duty.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. … [A] landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of [an] allegedly hazardous condition … cannot be found to have violated [a] duty of care.”

Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455.raw_text: Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455 Mass. 215 (2009)
Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff is entitled to recovery for all damages sustained pursuant to Massachusetts law, including G.L. c. 231, § 85, and the principles stated in Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455 Mass. 215 (2009).
Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455.case_name: Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc.
Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455.support_reasoning: Donovan recognizes that, under Massachusetts tort law, a plaintiff who proves negligence and certain subclinical physiological changes may recover medical monitoring expenses as a form of future medical expense. It does not state that a plaintiff is generically entitled to recover “all damages sustained” pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85, nor does it interpret or apply § 85 (comparative negligence). The case is about the cognizability and accrual of medical monitoring claims in toxic‑tort settings, not the full scope of recoverable damages under Massachusetts negligence law or § 85, so the proposition overstates what Donovan holds.
Donovan v. Philip Morris USA, Inc., 455.relevant_excerpt: “In this respect, medical expenses are recoverable not only for direct treatment and diagnosis of a present injury or an injury likely to occur, but for diagnostic tests needed to monitor medically a person who has been substantially exposed to a toxic substance that has created physiological changes indicating a substantial increase in risk that the person will contract a serious illness or disease. The expense of medical monitoring is thus a form of future medical expense and should be treated as such.”
